content.text: Steam, which is water in its gas phase, can significantly impact the opacity of a plume. EPA Method 9 specifically restricts opacity observations to areas of the plume where steam (water vapor) is absent. If steam is present, opacity observations must be conducted either before or after the section of the plume containing visible steam.

Steam plumes have multiple characteristics that aid in visual identification:

• The color is usually white or light gray.
• Their texture and appearance is similar to a cloud.
• The edges of the plume disappear as the vapor cools.
• As water vapor cools and condenses, the plume moves toward the ground.
There are two types of steam plumes; attached and detached.

images.caption: An attached steam plume is continuous with the stack. Water vapor has cooled and condensed within the stack.
Detached steam plumes are not continuous with the stack exit. There is a distinct gap between the stack and the formation of the plume. Water vapor condenses as it hits the cooler outside air.

sections.title: Reading Opacity When Steam is Present

content.text: The observer must take readings at a point in the plume where steam is absent. The type of steam plume will determine the appropriate observation point.

images.caption: Attached Steam Plume - Observe the plume at the greatest point of opacity after the steam dissipates.
Detached Steam Plume - Observe the plume at the greatest point of opacity before the formation of steam or after the point of dissipation.
